Fig. 1 Impact of modifier (M=Fe or Ni) addition at a molar ratio of M/C = 0.3 on the glycerol conversion of impregnated catalysts in glycerol hydrogenolysis. Reaction temperatures: (a) 230 °C and (b) 220 °C, pressure (P) = 7.0 MPa, feedstock: 80 wt% glycerol, 20 wt% water, in a continuous tube reactor. W/F (h): weight of catalyst (g)/feedstock flowrate (g/h). Fig. 1 Fig. 2 a) The influence of Fe/Cu ratio on the catalytic performance during the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction in a continuous tube reactor at 230 °C after 120 h (X1) or 220 °C after 156 h (X2), with a pressure of 7.0 MPa and a W/F ratio of 0.6 h; b) glycerol conversion and c) selectivity to 1,2-PD of prepared Cu and CuFe catalysts during the test in different conditions (t = 230 °C, p = 7 MPa, 80 wt% glycerol and different W/F ratios: Phase I. and I.d = 0.5 h, Phase II. and II.d = 0.6 h, Phase III. = 0.7 h, Phase IV. = 0.8 h, Phase V. = 1.0 h and Phase VI. = 1.6 h). Fig. 2 Fig. 3 XRD diffraction patterns of the catalysts prepared by the impregnation of alumina with Cu (Cu1) or combination of Cu and Fe (CuFe1 – 4) with different Cu/Fe ratio. Fig. 3 Fig. 4 Pore distribution (NLDFT method) of γ-alumina and the catalysts prepared by impregnation of the alumina with Cu or Cu+Fe. Fig. 4 Fig. 5 Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental maps of catalysts particles on the surface. Fig. 5 Fig. 6 Energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) elemental maps of the cross-section of a cylindrical catalyst particle. Fig. 6 Fig. 7 H2-TPR profiles of the catalysts prepared by impregnation of alumina with Cu (Cu1), Fe (Fe1) and the combination of Cu and Fe (CuFe1 – 4); 1 – very finely dispersed CuO particles; 2 – finely dispersed CuO particles; 3 – moderately dispersed CuO particles; 4 – clusters (bulk) of CuO; 5 – reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4. Fig. 7 Fig. 8 (a) XPS spectra of Cu2p, and (b) Cu LMM Auger spectra for the catalysts. Fig. 8 Fig. 9 (a) NH3-TPD of the Cu-based catalysts, (b) TOF and initial reaction rate for Cu-based catalysts, (c) correlation between catalyst acidity and Fe/Cu ratios, (d) glycerol conversion at different Fe/Cu ratios: continuous tube reactor at 230 °C with a pressure of 7.0 MPa and a W/F of 0.6 h. Fig. 9 Scheme 1 Schematic representation of the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction pathways [68]. ORLEN UniCRE, a.s Revoluční 1521/84 Ústí nad Labem 400 01 Czech Republic ⁎⁎ Corresponding author. This study introduces a novel Cu-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol, synthesized by impregnating mesoporous γ-alumina with Cu and Fe. Characterization was performed using various analytical methods, and tests were conducted in a tubular continuous reactor under specific conditions. Iron was found to have multiple modifying effects, influencing the modification of Cu clusters on the catalyst surface and the radial Cu concentration profile inside the particles. A low Fe/Cu ratio resulted in an almost egg-shell Cu profile, whereas higher Fe levels produced a more uniform distribution. Interestingly, minor Fe additions led to larger Cu clusters, while higher amounts resulted in smaller clusters and decreased glycerol conversion. The effect of Fe on Cu clusters size, acid sites concentration, and Cu radial profile, as well as the influence of these parameters on the glycerol conversion and selectivity towards 1,2-PD are discussed in this study. Graphical Abstract Keywords Glycerol hydrogenolysis Bimetallic Cu-Fe catalyst 1 2-Propanediol Heterogeneous catalysis Metal cluster size effect Acidity-selectivity relationship Data Availability No data was used for the research described in the article. 1 Introduction Selective hydrogenolysis of natural polyols to lower alcohols is a promising way of phasing out the fossil starting materials from the petrochemical production system. Glycerol is the simplest natural polyol once obtainable from soap production or even manufactured synthetically from propylene, now available in large quantities from FAME production. As one of the most popular platform compounds, glycerol has been intensively studied as a model molecule for the synthesis of many different fuels and value-added chemicals [1]. One of the promising routes of its utilization is its conversion to 1,2-propanediol (1,2-PD) and, theoretically, also to ethylene glycol by selective hydrogenolysis. 1,2-PD is a viscous, colorless liquid that is almost odorless and has a slightly sweet taste. There are three primary methods for obtaining 1,2-PD: a) the traditional conversion of propylene to propylene oxide followed by hydrolysis, b) hydrogenolysis of glycerol and sugar derivatives, as well as biotechnological methods using microorganisms and enzymatic catalysis, or c) the fermentation of sugars and glycerol. 1,2-PD is a promising chemical with numerous applications including its use as an antifreeze, cosmetic agent, moisturizer, solvent, surfactant, and a preservative [2]. Some commercial units producing propylene glycol from glycerol are already in run [3] though they seem to be far from technological maturity. There is still a space for improvement, mainly in the efficiency of the catalysts used for said hydrogenolysis process. Research on catalysts for glycerol hydrogenolysis can provide valuable insights applicable to the development of processes for the conversion of higher natural polyols, derived from biomass, into key chemical intermediates such as lower alcohols. These intermediates, crucial in various sectors of the chemical industry, are currently mainly derived from the petrochemical industry. The similarity between glycerol hydrogenolysis and the chemistry of higher natural polyols underscores the significance of catalyst research in providing valuable insights. This investigation not only deepens our understanding of glycerol hydrogenolysis but also contributes to the development of novel processes for transforming higher natural polyols derived from biomass into essential chemical intermediates, specifically lower alcohols. These lower alcohols, currently produced in large quantities by the petrochemical industry, are essential in various sectors of the chemical industry. Selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol is a heterogeneously catalyzed reaction. Noble metals, mainly Ru, Rh or Pd have been tested and verified as effective catalysts in this reaction [3]. Besides noble metals, the catalysts containing Cu as the main active metal have been most frequently studied for this reaction [3,4]. Their main advantage over noble metals lies in their cost-effectiveness, while maintaining comparable kinetic parameters such as activity and selectivity. Typically synthesized through precipitation or co-precipitation methods, these catalysts exhibit excellent selectivity for 1,2-PD, particularly at reasonable activity levels, especially when fine copper particles form during precipitation. This process takes place under circumstances favorable for the formation of hydrotalcite-like (double-layered) structures as intermediates [5–7]. However, the mechanical stability of precipitated Cu-based catalysts in water-containing reaction media presents a significant challenge. Utilizing supported catalysts through impregnation on industrially proven supports appears to be a viable solution to address this issue. Zeolites are frequently employed as acid catalysts in industrial applications, yet they also serve as catalyst supports. They have been extensively utilized as supports for catalysts in the direct hydrogenolysis of glycerol [8–11]. Silica has also been a prevalent choice as a catalyst support [12–17]. Significant focus has been directed towards understanding the interactions between Cu and Si, which likely play a crucial role in determining the properties of this system. It has been observed that finer Cu dispersion is achieved with smaller silica particles. γ-alumina is likely the most widely employed support for Cu catalysts in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol [17–30]. It can be constructed not only into high-strength particles but also displays significant benefits, including a substantial surface area and a high density of acidic centers on its surface [22]. In addition to commonly employed catalyst supports like silica and alumina, MgO has undergone multiple studies for the development of Cu-based hydrogenolysis catalysts [31–33]. These catalysts have been evaluated in both gas phase [31] and liquid phase [32] reactions. Notably, they exhibited high selectivity for 1,2-PD, with minimal formation of lower molecular products, as the C-C bond cleavage was effectively suppressed on MgO [31]. Copper catalysts on different supports (γ-alumina, SiO2, MgO, ZnO) were evaluated through tests in the glycerol hydrothermal hydrogenolysis process without the addition of external hydrogen [17]. Cu/MgO was evaluated as the most catalyst. However, the study [19] also pointed out that the Cu leaching during the reaction was the main problem of this catalyst. The Cu-containing catalysts have been often modified by the addition of other transition metals. Silver has been described several times as being an efficient modifier of the Cu based catalysts [18,19,21]. It was emphasized that a more effective outcome with silver (Ag) could be attained when employing a one-step impregnation method using a bimetallic solution (containing Cu and Ag salts), as opposed to a two-step process involving subsequent impregnation with monometallic solutions [19]. Another study provides a comparison of Cu/Al2O3 and Ag-modified Cu/Al2O3 catalysts [21]. Although the addition of Ag reduced the activity of the catalyst to some extent, it caused an increase of the selectivity to 1,2-PD on the account of ethylene glycol formation. Alumina is not considered an inert support; it contains acidic centers on its surface that can actively participate in the hydrogenolysis of glycerol. Hydration of alumina by water, which is both present in the feedstock and formed by the reaction, results in the blocking of these centers, which leads to a decrease in the activity of the catalyst [22]. The catalytic performance of the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst, modified by the incorporation of boron trioxide, was also assessed [23]. The results revealed that the addition of boric oxide enhanced catalytic activity and significantly contributed to a high selectivity for 1,2-PD. Bimetallic Cu-Ni catalysts, prepared through the impregnation of alumina, have been extensively investigated [24–30]. Additionally, the kinetics of glycerol hydrogenolysis over this catalyst have been studied [24]. The impact of the Ni/Cu ratio on the properties of the catalyst, prepared by impregnating metal salts on γ-alumina, has also been examined [26]. As revealed in the previously reported study [26], the Ni/Cu ratio significantly affects the properties of the catalysts. Ni catalyzes C-C bond cleavage, resulting in low molecular products (down to CH4), while Cu predominantly facilitates the dehydration to acetol (a precursor of 1,2-PD formation). Consequently, the overall catalyst activity decreases with a decrease in the Ni/Cu ratio, but simultaneously, there is an improvement in the selectivity to 1,2-PD. In a study by Pudi et al. [27], a comparison of monometallic Cu and Ni catalysts on alumina with the bimetallic Cu-Ni catalyst was conducted. It was observed that the bimetallic catalyst with a Cu:Ni ratio of 1:1 exhibited the most favorable properties. At 210 °C and 4.5 MPa, the selectivity of hydrogenolysis to 1,2-PD reached 92.8 % with a 72 % glycerol conversion. The advantageous catalytic properties of the bimetallic catalyst were attributed to the large surface area of the metallic phase, small metal particles, and a high concentration of acidic centers. Bimetallic catalysts of the CuZnAl type have also been the subject of investigation in previous studies [7,34,35]. For instance, Yfanti [34] explored a tandem catalytic cycle involving methanol aqueous phase reforming and glycerol hydro-deoxygenation, targeting the production of 1,2-propanediol using CuZnAl bulk catalysts. In another work [7], a series of tests were performed with Cu-Zn-Al oxide catalysts in a stirred-tank reactor at 230 °C. The findings revealed that Zn acts as a structure modifier in the catalysts, affecting Cu dispersion and particle size, consequently influencing the catalyst activity. The highest effect of Zn was observed at a Zn/(Cu+Al) ratio of 0.35, where a glycerol conversion of 65 % and a 1,2-PD selectivity of 70 % were achieved after 60 minutes of reaction time. Furthermore, in a separate study [35], the impact of preparation methods on the structure of the Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst and its catalytic activity in the hydrogenolysis of liquid glycerol to 1,2-PD was investigated. At 200 °C and 2.7 MPa hydrogen pressure, the catalyst prepared by oxalate gel coprecipitation exhibited a glycerol conversion of 94.5 % and a 1,2-PD selectivity. Iron has not frequently been reported as a modifier of Cu-based hydrogenolysis catalysts. However, in an earlier study [5], it was characterized as an effective modifier for precipitated Cu catalysts prepared from hydrotalcite-like structures. This observation prompted an exploration of its impact on impregnated catalysts prepared with a mechanically stable support. The objective of this study is to assess and elucidate the influence of iron as a modifier of Cu-based catalysts, specifically those prepared through the impregnation of γ-alumina. These catalysts were subjected to testing in the laboratory hydrogenolysis of glycerol in the liquid phase. 2 Experimental 2.1 Catalyst preparation γ-alumina (Eurosupport Manuf. Czechia) in the form of cylindrical extrudates, with both the length and the diameter of 3 mm, was used as the catalyst support. Cu(NO3)2‧3 H2O, Fe(NO3)3‧9 H2O (Sigma Aldrich) and deionized water were employed for the preparation of impregnation solutions. The catalysts were prepared according to the following procedure: 30 g of extruded alumina was placed in a vacuum evaporator flask and evacuated to 0.7 kPa at 50 °C, and maintained at these conditions for 0.5 h. Subsequently, an aqueous solution containing the required amount of precursors, for example, 15 g of Cu(NO3)2‧3 H2O and 7.2 g of Fe(NO3)3‧9 H2O in 50 ml of water, was added dropwise at a rotating flask with a constant speed (∼100 rpm). Following the completion of the addition of impregnation aqueous solution, the flask containing the mixture of the solution was kept rotating for 30 minutes. The temperature of the mixture was then increased to 70 °C, and stirring continued for an additional 30 minutes. Subsequently, the pressure in the evaporator was increased to atmospheric pressure. The saturated intermediate was extracted from the flask, spread on a baking sheet, and dried in an oven, initially at 100 °C for 2 h, followed by 120 °C for an additional 3 h. The dried material was then calcined in a laboratory oven, with the temperature incrementing from room temperature at a rate of 100 °C.h−1 to a final temperature of 450 °C, maintaining this final temperature for 2 hours. The calcination in the presence of air converted the metal salts into oxides. 2.2 Catalysts characterization All catalyst characterization analyses were conducted on the synthesized catalysts after calcination, without any pretreatment prior to analysis. The catalysts were not subjected to reduction before undergoing characterization. Metal content in the catalyst samples was determined using Inductively Coupled Plasma with Optical Emission Spectrometry (ICP-OES). An ICP-EOS Agilent 725 spectrometer (Agilent Technologies Inc., Santa Clara, CA, United States) equipped with echelle optics and a CCD detector was employed for this analysis. Each sample underwent wet decomposition in preparation for the analysis. The crystallographic structure of all synthesized catalyst samples in powder form was determined through X-ray diffraction (XRD) analyses using D8 Advance ECO (Bruker AXS GmbH, Karlsruhe, Germany) equipped with a CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å). The XRD analysis utilized a step size of 0.02° with a step time of 0.5 s. The patterns were collected in the 2θ range between 5–70° and evaluated using DIFFRAC.EVA software with the Powder Diffraction File database (PDF 4+ 2018, International Centre for Diffraction Data). Textural properties of the catalysts, including specific surface area, pore volume, and pore size, were determined using the N 2 physisorption method. Prior to measurement, the samples underwent degassing under vacuum at 473 K for 2 hours. Subsequently, adsorption and desorption isotherms were measured at the temperature of liquid nitrogen (-195.8 °C). The specific surface area was calculated from the linear plot of the adsorption isotherm using the Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller (BET) method, with a pressure range in the interval between 0.05–0.30 P/P0. The pore size distribution was determined utilizing non-local density functional theory (NLDFT), which describes the behavior of absorptive molecules in the gas phase and inside the pores. Both the degassing and the measurement were conducted using the Autosorb iQ device (Quantachrome Instruments, Boynton Beach, FL, USA). The reducibility of the catalysts was assessed through hydrogen temperature-programmed reduction (H 2 -TPR). Experiments were conducted using the Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 device (Micromeritics Corp., USA), equipped with a thermal conductivity detector. The reduction process carried out in a flow of reducing gas, consisting of 10 vol% H2 in Ar (50 ml.min−1). A powdered sample weighing 100 mg was positioned in a quartz reactor, and the sample underwent thermal pre-treatment at a gradually increasing temperature (at a ramping rate of 10 °C.min−1 up to 300 °C), followed by a 10-minute stabilization at the final temperature. The water generated during the H2-TPR process is captured by a cold trap consisting of a mixture of isopropanol and liquid nitrogen. The X-ray photoelectron spectroscopy (XPS) spectra of the samples were obtained using an XPS instrument within a high-vacuum chamber. The instrument was equipped with a SPECS X-ray XR50 source (SPECS Surface Nano Analysis GmbH, Germany), employing both an Al anode (1486.6 eV) and a Mg anode (1253.6 eV). The sample charging was neutralized using an electron source delivering 4 eV energy and approximately 26uA current, which proved to be the optimal setting for these samples. Analysis was conducted using a SPECS PHOIBOS 100 electron energy analyzer equipped with an X-Ray 50 monochromated FOCUS 500, Flood Gun (FG) 35 charge compensation, with an energy resolution of <10 meV for XPS and Auger resolution of <0.5°, and a 5-channel Channeltron detector, operated via a 5-axis SPECS manipulator. Charge compensation adjustments were made to minimize the half-width of the Al2p peak during measurements, followed by normalizing the Al2p peak to 74.1 eV. Thermo Scientific™ Avantage Software was used for the processing of the obtained data. The specific surface area of copper on the reduced catalysts were determined using reactive frontal chromatography with N 2 O (N 2 O-RFC). Experiments were conducted with the Micromeritics Auto Chem II 2920 device (Micromeritics Corp., USA), equipped with the OmniStarTM GSD 320 mass spectrometer (Pfeiffer Vacuum, Germany). The experimental setup and data evaluation details were previously described [36]. In a typical experiment, the catalyst sample (approximately 200 mg) underwent reduction at 250 °C (10 vol% H2 in Ar), followed by flushing and cooling to 90 °C (He), and subsequent copper surface passivation at 90 °C (2 vol% of N2O in He). Measurements were carried out with a temperature ramp of 10 °C.min−1 and a gas flow rate of 25 ml.min−1. The amount of N2 evolved during the N2O reaction with Cu was calculated based on mass spectrometry calibration at mass 28. The specific surface area of copper was determined considering 0.697 × 1019 atoms of O per m2 of Cu. The cluster size of Cu was calculated using the following equation (Eq. 1): (1) Cu cluster size = 3 ρ Cu × S ( Cu ) where: ρ(Cu) is the copper density (8.96 g cm−3), and S(Cu) is the copper specific surface area (cm2 gCu −1). Please note that the calculation of Cu cluster size considered the hemisphere model. The morphology of the samples and the concentration profiles of metals were investigated using a scanning electron microscope (SEM) JSMIT500Hr from JEOL (JEOL Ltd., Tokyo, Japan). The microscope operated at an accelerating voltage of 15 kV with a secondary electron detector (SED). The working distance was set at 10 mm, and the magnification range ranged from 500× to 10,000×. Elemental mapping analysis was conducted using an energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS) probe. Prior to analysis, the samples were coated with approximately 5 nm of gold to enhance conductivity and prevent charging during the microscope observation. 2.3 Experimental setup and catalysts testing 2.3.1 Catalytic reaction Catalyst tests were conducted in a tubular stainless steel flow reactor (Vinci Technologies, France) featuring an internal diameter of 9 mm, allowing concurrent flow of both gas and liquid phases. The liquid injection and gas input (H2) were introduced to the upper section of the reactor, while the product (liquid/gas) was withdrawn from the lower part and directed to the liquid-gas separator. The gas quantity at the outlet of the liquid-gas separator was measured using a wet gas meter after pressure release. The substrate (carborundum, 1–3 mm) and the impregnated catalyst (7 g) were loaded into the reactor. The test commenced with in-situ activation, involving catalyst pre-reduction. This process began by purging the catalyst bed with nitrogen at a flow rate of 50 l.h−1 at 7 MPa, while heating the reactor at a rate of 2 °C.min−1 up to 100 °C. Once 100 °C was reached, nitrogen was replaced with hydrogen, maintaining a constant flow rate. The heating continued at a rate of 2 °C.min−1 up to a temperature of 350 °C. At 350 °C, the hydrogen flow was reduced to 30 l.h−1, and the unit was left without further intervention for 4 hours. Subsequently, the unit was cooled down to 230 °C at a constant hydrogen flow. Upon reaching 230 °C, the hydrogen flow rate was increased to 70 l.h−1, and the feed of the raw material (80 wt% glycerol, 20 wt% water) was initiated at a rate of 14 g.h−1. The feedstock and hydrogen feeds were adjusted proportionally throughout the experiment. 2.3.2 Product analyses The products of glycerol hydrogenolysis were analyzed using the gas chromatography (GC) method with an Agilent 7890 device equipped with a Nukol™ (Supelco) capillary column (30 m length, 0.32 mm ID, 0.25 μm film thickness). The analysis conditions were as follows: helium as the carrier gas, input pressure of 30 kPa, gasifier temperature of 320 °C, and flame ionization detector (FID) temperature of 320 °C. The oven temperature program commenced at 60 °C, with a temperature ramp of 5 °C.min−1 up to 160 °C. Subsequently, the temperature increased at a rate of 10 °C.min−1 in the temperature range between 160 – 200 °C. The final stage of the temperature program involved an isotherm at 200 °C maintained for 30 minutes. Quantitative determination of individual products was carried out using the internal standard method with 3-methylbutanol as the internal standard. The conversion and product selectivity in the liquid phase were calculated based on the following Eqs. 2 and 3: (2) Glycerol conversion % = initial mol of glycerol − unconverted mole of glycerol initial mol of glycerol × 100 (3) Liquid phase selectivity [ % ] = mol of specific product in liquid phase sum of mol of all product in liquid phase × 100 3 Results and discussion In the initial set of experiments, Cu/γ-alumina impregnated catalysts, modified with either Fe or Ni, were prepared and evaluated in a tube continuous laboratory reactor. The modifying metal (M) was added in an amount corresponding to a M/Cu molar ratio of 0.3. The catalytic performances of these catalysts was compared with that of a monometallic catalyst containing the same quantity of Cu, prepared through the impregnation of an identical support (γ-alumina) ( Fig. 1). Notably, the catalyst prepared without the addition of Fe contained traces of this metal, particularly 136 ppm, as determined by ICP, originally present as an impurity in the starting material. Different W/F (h) (weight of catalyst (g)/feedstock flowrate (g/h)) values were attained by adjusting the reactant flow rate within a single experiment. To assess the stability of catalyst, at the final stage of the experiment, the reactant flow rate was returned to its initial setting. Throughout the evaluation of a specific catalyst, the conditions (W/F and temperature) were changed successively, always simultaneously. The primary objective of the initial phase of the study was to assess and compare the effectiveness of Fe and Ni as modifiers of impregnated catalysts, with Cu serving as the main active metal. As depicted in Fig. 1, the addition of Ni, at the specified molar ratio, negatively affected the catalyst conversion, while a noticeable positive effect was observed with the addition of Fe at an equivalent molar amount. The catalyst modified with Fe achieved complete glycerol conversion after 1.1 hours (W/F) at a temperature of 230 °C, whereas it reached approximately 90 % after 1.7 hours over the unmodified and Ni-modified catalysts under identical reaction conditions. Throughout the entire reaction duration and at both reaction temperatures of 220 °C and 230 °C, the Fe-modified catalysts exhibited higher conversion in the same time compared to the other two catalysts. The glycerol conversion was calculated for each test after 120 hours of testing at 230 °C and 156 hours of testing at 220 °C. The selectivity values for 1,2-PD were comparable for all mentioned catalysts (refer to Table 1). Subsequently, catalysts modified with Fe underwent more detailed investigation in the subsequent phases of the research. Catalysts with different amounts of Fe, featuring a wide range of Fe:Cu molar ratios (see Table 2), were investigated. The comparison between theoretical and real metal concentrations, as presented in Table 2, reveals a small difference between the two values. In some instances, the ICP analysis yields slightly higher real metal concentrations, while in other cases, the theoretical values are marginally higher. These variations are likely due to the inevitable losses of metal during the preparation steps, which can result in slight deviations between the expected and actual metal concentrations. The results of activity tests for these catalysts are presented in Fig. 2, where glycerol conversion values for different catalysts under identical reaction conditions, i.e., temperature, pressure, and W/F, are compared. As it is suitable to compare the conversion values at the conditions where these values are safely below the full conversion, sufficiently short W/F (0.6 h) was selected for this comparison. It is evident from Fig. 2(a) that small amounts of Fe, up to a Fe:Cu ratio of 0.05 (CuFe1), had a clearly positive effect on the glycerol conversion. Subsequently, the glycerol conversion remained almost constant up to Fe:Cu=0.15, and an apparent decrease in conversion was observed for higher values of the Fe:Cu ratio. The question was whether iron directly influenced the formation of active catalytic species or acted as a structure modifier, impacting the surface character or, potentially, the deposition of active Cu particles. To ascertain a potential catalytic effect of iron itself, a catalyst without Cu was prepared by impregnating alumina with a monometallic solution containing only Fe(NO3)3. The iron load was identical to that in the CuFe3 catalyst, and the preparation process remained the same. Testing this catalyst at 230 °C and 7 MPa revealed practically zero conversion, as only traces (around 10−3 wt%) of 1,2-PD were detected in the product, with negligible glycerol conversion. This experiment confirmed that neither the deposition of Fe nor alumina itself contained active centers necessary for the hydrogenolysis reaction to initiate, despite the presence of strong acidic centers undoubtedly present on the alumina surface before impregnation. The addition of a small amount of iron to the copper catalyst appears to have a beneficial effect on the catalytic activity and stability during glycerol hydrogenolysis. As mentioned, the Fe monometallic catalyst did not exhibit any catalytic activity, while the Cu catalyst showed some inherent activity. This suggests that copper is the primary active metal responsible for the catalytic transformation of glycerol. However, the incorporation of a minor quantity of Fe into the Cu catalyst structure led to an increase in glycerol conversion and improved the overall catalytic stability compared to the Cu catalyst alone. One possible explanation for this observation is the potential partial reduction of Fe in the presence of Cu due to hydrogen spillover effects. Hydrogen spillover is a phenomenon where hydrogen atoms dissociatively adsorbed on one metal (e.g., Cu) can migrate to and be absorbed by another metal (e.g., Fe), facilitating its reduction. This interaction between Cu and Fe can alter the redox properties of the catalyst, potentially enhancing the reducibility of Fe and promoting the formation of active sites [37]. The monometallic Fe catalyst may not undergo significant reduction at the temperature of 350°C, as the reduction of Fe typically occurs at higher temperatures, typically above 400°C. The lack of a reducing environment could limit the extent of Fe reduction in the monometallic catalyst, leading to a less active catalyst compared to the Cu-Fe bimetallic system. The improved catalytic stability observed with the addition of Fe to the Cu catalyst could be attributed to several factors. The partial reduction of Fe and the formation of Cu-Fe interactions may create new active sites or modify the existing ones, leading to enhanced catalytic activity. Additionally, the presence of Fe may help to stabilize the Cu species, preventing their sintering or leaching during the reaction, thereby enhancing the overall stability of the catalyst. In brief, the addition of a small amount of Fe to the Cu catalyst appears to have a beneficial effect on the catalytic activity and stability during glycerol hydrogenolysis. The potential partial reduction of Fe due to hydrogen spillover from Cu and the formation of Cu-Fe interactions may contribute to the observed improvements. However, more detailed investigations are necessary to fully elucidate the underlying mechanisms and the role of Fe in modifying the catalytic properties of the Cu-based catalyst. Fig. 2(b) depicts the conversion of glycerol over time-of-stream (TOS) using Cu and CuFe 1–4 catalysts. Fig. 2(c) illustrates the selectivity to 1,2-PD during the same period. The W/F was gradually changed throughout the test, resulting in several phases of experiment. The CuFe1 catalyst achieved the highest conversion in nearly all test phases. Interestingly, the CuFe4 catalyst, which had the lowest conversion in all other phases, exhibited surprisingly high glycerol conversion during the final phase (phase VI, W/F= 1.6 h). The CuFe2 catalyst demonstrated the greatest selectivity across all test phases. To assess catalyst deactivation, each test concluded by resetting the reaction conditions to their initial state, including the same W/F ratio as at the beginning. These final phases are labeled I.d and II.d in Fig. 2(b,c). The final two phases evaluate the resistance of prepared catalysts to deactivation and compare their deactivation behavior. The results indicate that a small amount of Fe addition enhances the catalyst's resistance to deactivation. The catalyst without Fe (Cu1) and with high Fe content (CuFe4) exhibited significantly lower glycerol conversion and 1,2-PD selectivity compared to the beginning of the test. In contrast, CuFe1 and CuFe2 catalysts demonstrated significantly greater resistance to deactivation, with comparable 1,2-PD selectivity at the beginning and end of the test. Table 3 shows the glycerol conversion and 1,2-PD yields for the two best catalysts, CuFe1 and CuFe2, at different W/F ratios. The highest 1,2-PD yields (90 %) were achieved with the CuFe2 catalyst at a W/F of 0.7, corresponding to a W/F ratio of 0.8 h. The data indicates that glycerol conversion and 1,2-PD yield decreased at the end of the test, as the reaction conditions returned to their initial setting values. This decline in activity implies a gradual partial deactivation of both CuFe1 and CuFe2 catalysts throughout the test. The deactivation is likely attributed to the initial leaching of copper and iron from the catalyst, which can lead to a reduction in its activity. The crystal structure of the prepared catalysts was determined through X-ray diffraction. Prominent diffraction lines at 2theta of 32.5°, 35.5°, 38.8°, 48.7°, 53.3°, 58.3°, and 61.5° in the diffraction pattern ( Fig. 3) can be attributed to CuO (Powder Diffraction File database PDF 4+ 2018 – file PDF 05–0661), while the lines at 2theta of 36.7°, 45.8°, and 66.9° are characteristic for Al2O3 (PDF 88–1609), i.e., the catalyst support. Another solid phase is visible in the diffraction pattern at 2theta of 33.4°. The intensity of this signal increases with rising Fe content. Although the identification of this phase is not entirely clear, it is most likely a result of the interaction between Fe and Al2O3 (PDF 30–0024). Only minor differences among the various catalyst samples are observed in the diffraction pattern. However, it is apparent that the intensity of the main signals (2theta of 35.5° or 38.8°, respectively) decreases with increasing Fe content. This suggests that the addition of Fe leads to an improvement in the crystallinity of the CuO phase, potentially contributing to the increase in glycerol conversion. N2 physisorption measurements revealed that all catalyst samples were fundamentally mesoporous materials. The N2 isotherms were classified as type IV, according to IUPAC (refer to Fig. S3). The confirmation of mesopores is evident from a hysteresis loop, characterized as type H1. Type H1 represents materials with a narrow size distribution of uniform pores [38]. This observation had been expected, as all the samples were prepared by impregnation of mesoporous alumina. The pore size distribution of the studied catalysts determined by the NLDF model, shows that pores belong to the interval from 5 to 15 nm, the interval having its maximum at 11 nm, ( Fig. 4). The amount of Fe did not substantially influence the pore size distribution, which mainly corresponds to pure alumina. Only a slight shift to a lower pore size in the area of larger pores was observed. This can be explained by the gradual filling of the pores of alumina by Fe and Cu oxides. Moreover, a slight decrease in the pore volume was observed with the increase of Fe content. Specific pore sizes were determined from the adsorption part of the isotherm at a relative pressure between 0.01 and 0.30 using the BET method ( Table 4). The determined specific surface area of alumina at 257 m2.g−1 falls within the typical range reported for mesoporous alumina [39]. The impregnation of the catalysts led to a certain decrease in specific surface area as well as a reduction in pore volume due to the filling of the pores with Fe and Cu oxides. The presence of micropores was not observed, with only meso- and macropores being detected in the catalysts. Approximately 98 % of the total pore volume falls into the category of mesopores. Both the total pore volume and the mesopore volume gradually decreased from 0.799 (pure alumina – support) to 0.783 cm3.g−1 (CuFe4 with the highest Fe concentration). Hg porosimetry provided a similar depiction of the catalysts pore structure (see Figures S1, S2, and Table S1), thus confirming the conclusions drawn from N2 physisorption analysis. Copper distribution on both the surface ( Fig. 5) and inside (in the cross-section of a cylindrical catalyst particle) the catalyst particles ( Fig. 6) was examined using energy-dispersive X-ray spectroscopy (EDS). The EDS analysis was employed to determine the surface concentration of Cu, with the copper content (wt%) on the catalyst surfaces ordered as follows: CuFe1 (63.8 %) > CuFe2 (41.7 %) > Cu1 (31.9 %) > CuFe3 (28.4 %) > CuFe4 (14.9 %). Notably, the Cu concentration on the CuFe1 surface even surpasses that on the catalyst prepared without Fe addition (Cu1), while an increase in iron content leads to a decreased copper content on the surface. The concentration of Cu and Fe inside the catalyst particles (Fig. 6) exhibit an intriguing dependence on Fe addition. The copper concentration (wt%) across the cross-section of the catalyst particles is ordered as follows: CuFe1 (16.7 %) < CuFe2 (17.7 %) < Cu1 (17.8 %) < CuFe3 (21 %) < CuFe4 (21.1 %). A small amount of Fe, corresponding to the Fe/Cu ratio of 0.050 (CuFe1), causes the formation of a typical egg-shell profile for both Cu and Fe concentrations (see Fig. 7). A homogeneous iron distribution was not observed in the cross-section of the catalyst, the Fe profile changing gradually from egg-shell to egg- white type with increasing Fe concentration (see Fig. 6). The rate of metal ion adsorption depends primarily on the following parameters: the adsorption constant of the specific ion, temperature, ion concentration, pH of the solution [40], and the type of counter-ion (anion) [41]. The final metal concentration profile is not only a consequence of primary adsorption but also involves metal redistributions during drying, particularly noteworthy for weakly adsorbed ions [40]. The preparation conditions, including impregnation temperature and pressure, speed of metal solution dosing, carrier pre-treatment, drying, and calcination temperature values, were kept constant in all catalyst preparations within the scope of this study. However, the pH of the bimetallic solution used for impregnation was significantly dependent on the concentration of Fe(NO3)3 (see Table 2). The different strengths of adsorption of Cu and Fe also need to be considered. According to some previous studies [41], the adsorption constant of Fe was almost two orders of magnitude higher than the adsorption constant of Cu. In the cross-section elemental mapping images (Fig. 6), a practically uniform concentration profile was achieved when preparing the monometallic Cu catalyst (Cu1). A small addition of Fe resulted in a typical egg-shell Fe concentration profile, with a thin layer of highly concentrated Cu on the catalyst surface and immediately below it (Figs. 6 and 7). Further increases in Fe concentration in the impregnation solution led to significant changes in the Fe profile. It gradually shaped into a typical egg-white profile, consistent with the findings of previous studies [40,41]. Simultaneously, the Cu surface concentration gradually decreased, and its profile became completely uniform, most probably due to weaker adsorption resulting from the decrease in the pH of the impregnation solution (see Table 2). The final Cu profile was thus established during catalyst drying. It is evident that Fe, as a more strongly adsorbed metal ion, affected Cu adsorption, having a considerable impact on the formation of the final Cu profile. The catalyst samples with higher Cu concentration near the support surface (CuFe1, CuFe2) exhibited higher glycerol conversion despite less Cu dispersion (Fig. 2), as the active sites on these particles are easily accessible for glycerol molecules. Fig. 7 illustrates the H2-TPR profiles for the synthesized catalysts. The reduction behavior of CuO is a complex process, characterized by specific stages: Cu2+ to Cu+ at low temperatures (<230 °C), followed by Cu+ to Cu0 at temperatures above 800 °C [42–44]. The obtained TPR spectra for the catalysts showed split peaks (peaks 1 and 2), which are attributed to the reduction of smaller and larger Cu particles, respectively. The appearance of an additional peak around 220 °C in specific samples (Cu1, CuFe1, and CuFe2) is associated with distinct structures and reactivities of CuO species within the catalyst. Peak 4 (at 260 °C) should be attributed to the reduction of bulk CuO, which had weaker interaction with the support, and corresponds to the larger particles. Similar results have been obtained in previous studies [45–48]. Signal 5 corresponds to the reduction of Fe2O3 to Fe3O4, validated through comparison with previously published results [49]. Real hydrogen consumption during the reduction of the catalyst, according to H2-TPR analysis, follows the order (Table 4): CuFe1 > CuFe2 > CuFe3 > CuFe4 > Cu, confirming the higher reducibility of the CuFe1 catalyst. The data presented in Table 4 compares the actual hydrogen consumption with the theoretical hydrogen consumption. The reduction of Fe typically occurs at higher temperatures, typically above 400°C, and no additional peaks were detected at higher temperatures in TPR. Thus, it is inferred that the conversion of Cu2+ to Cu+ is the only reaction taking place. Given the assumption of only partial reduction of Cu2+ to Cu+, the theoretical hydrogen consumption is calculated based on the amount of H2 required for this reduction step. For catalysts containing iron additives, the calculated theoretical hydrogen consumption is lower than the observed real consumption, with the largest difference observed for catalysts with the lowest iron content. The hard reducibility and consequently higher reduction temperatures of the catalysts indicate stronger metal-support interactions. The low-temperature peak is attributed to the reduction of CuOx clusters, indicative of weak interaction with the support, while the high-temperature reduction peak is associated with the strong interaction of the Cu-Al-Ox structure [50]. Also, the metal-support interaction decreased with increasing size of the copper particles [51]. The addition of a small amount of iron (CuFe1 and CuFe2) was observed to cause a slight decrease of the reduction temperature, and with further increases of iron content, a slight shift towards higher temperatures was observed. The addition of a small amount of iron resulted in an increase of the Cu cluster size, as confirmed by N2O-RFC (please refer to Table 4). The Cu cluster size increased from 5.30 nm in the Cu catalyst to 18.06 nm in the CuFe2 catalyst, and then decreased to 7.36 nm in the CuFe4 catalyst. Cu surface was growing in line with the Cu cluster size decrease (see Table 4), in dependence on the Fe concentration increase. Surprisingly, the glycerol conversion decreased in this line. Most probably, the effect of Cu axial profile overweighed the entire Cu surface effect. It indicates again that he reaction takes place preferably in a surface layer of the catalysts particles while the inside Cu deposits had lower effect. The contribution of the phase boundary of the metal particles is indeed a crucial aspect to consider in the catalytic discussion. In the context of the CuFe/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts, the interface between the porous phase of alumina and the metal particles plays an important role in the catalytic process. This interface, also known as the grain boundary (GB) phase, is a critical region where the properties of the materials can differ significantly from those of the bulk phases. While it is challenging to separate the effect of the copper particle size from the influence of the phase boundary, it is essential to acknowledge the relationship between these two factors. The GB phase can exhibit distinct properties compared to the bulk metal, such as altered diffusivity, reactivity, and mechanical behavior. In the case of CuFe alloys, small amount of Cu can influence the precipitation kinetics and mechanical properties of these alloys. However, the presence of Cu can also lead to susceptibility to intergranular corrosion (IGC), which can impact the stability and performance of catalyst [52–56]. To better understand the role of the phase boundary, it is necessary to consider the complex interaction between the metal particles, the support material, and the reactants. The GB phase can act as a site for reactant adsorption, influencing the catalytic activity and selectivity. Furthermore, the GB phase can also affect the metal particle size and distribution, which in turn can impact the catalytic performance. It can be concluded that while separating the effect of the copper particle size from the influence of the phase boundary is a complex task, it is essential to consider the relationship between these factors to gain a comprehensive understanding of the catalytic process. Further studies in the future are needed to elucidate the role of the GB phase in CuFe/Al2O3 impregnated catalysts and to develop strategies for optimizing the catalyst design and performance. XPS analysis served as the principal method for investigating the surface composition and elemental oxidation states of the samples under examination. The atomic ratios of Fe/Cu for the catalysts were also determined via XPS analysis, as shown in Table 2. The results confirmed that by increasing the iron content, the Fe/Cu ratio increased, which was further confirmed by the increasing mass ratios observed through inductively coupled plasma (ICP) analysis. The difference between the higher atomic ratios of Fe/Cu obtained from XPS analysis compared to the expected ratios based on ICP analysis could be attributed to the different sampling depths of the two techniques. The higher Fe/Cu ratios observed in XPS analysis in contrast to those from ICP analysis suggest a higher accumulation of Fe on the catalyst's surface compared to the overall bulk composition. XPS is highly surface-sensitive, analyzing only the outermost few nanometers of the catalyst, while ICP provides an average composition of the entire sample [57]. The EDS mapping results, which indicate that copper and iron are not solely present on the surface but may have penetrated into the catalyst (cross-section), provide further evidence that the surface composition differs from the bulk. This could be due to factors such as uneven distribution of the metals during catalyst preparation or preferential segregation of one metal to the surface. The combination of surface-sensitive XPS and bulk-sensitive ICP analysis, along with EDS mapping, suggests that the copper and iron in the catalyst are not uniformly distributed on the surface of the catalysts, which is affecting the catalytic performances during the reaction. Fig. 8 illustrates the XPS spectrum of Cu 2p in catalysts with distinct compositions. Within the Cu 2p spectra, the features at 931.8 and 951.5 eV are attributed to the Cu 2p3/2 and 2p1/2 peaks of Cu2O, respectively [58,59]. Additionally, peaks at 933.6 and 954.5 eV correspond to the Cu 2p3/2 and Cu 2p1/2 peaks of CuO, respectively. The introduction of iron into the catalyst structure resulted in an augmentation of Cu+, evidenced by a Cu+/Cu2+ ratio of 2.1 and 1.94 in CuFe1 and CuFe2 catalysts, respectively (refer to Table 4). This increase in Cu+ content can be rationalized by the higher electronegativity of Cu (1.9) in comparison to Fe (1.83), leading to a greater affinity of Cu for capturing electrons. Consequently, Cu2+ accepts electrons, generating more Cu+ and Cu0 (Cu2+ + e − → Cu+, E = +0.19 V, Cu2+ + 2 e − → Cu0, E = +0.34 V) [59,60], thereby shifting the redox reaction (Cu2+ + Fe2+ ↔ Fe3+ + Cu+) to the right. Further increase in Fe content, however, resulted in a decreased Cu+/Cu2+ ratio. It is seen that the binding energy for the CuFe3 and CuFe4 catalysts are slightly higher than that for other catalysts. These observations are aligned with the results of H2-TPR analysis, where the catalyst with the lowest iron content had the highest hydrogen consumption (Table 4), and it had the slightly lower reduction temperature compared with other catalysts. The Auger electron spectroscopy analysis offers valuable insights into the surface composition and chemical state analysis of the CuFe catalysts. Auger analysis is a surface-sensitive technique that measures the kinetic energy of Auger electrons emitted from the sample surface as a result of a two-step relaxation process following the initial ionization by an X-ray photon. This method is particularly useful for understanding the elemental composition and chemical environment at the surface of materials, which is critical for catalysts [61,62]. While XPS provides the oxidation states and binding energies, Auger analysis can further quantify the relative amounts of different oxidation states present at the surface. By examining the intensity of the Auger peaks, it is possible to gauge the concentration of Cu+, Cu2+, and potentially Cu0 on the surface, offering a quantitative understanding of how these species are distributed within the catalyst surface. This capability is crucial for confirming the oxidation states of copper deduced from the XPS Cu 2p core-level spectra. Auger spectroscopy enhances XPS analysis by offering additional insights into the electronic structure assessment conducted using XPS. When combined, these methods offer a comprehensive view of both the chemical composition and electronic characteristics of the catalyst surfaces. The Auger spectrum (Cu LMM transitions) provides a direct measurement of the chemical state of copper, the presence of Cu+ and Cu2+ can be distinguished based on the shifts in the kinetic energy of the emitted Auger electrons. The data illustrates a distinct and prominent peak at approximately 916.2 eV kinetic energy, corresponding to Cu+ (Fig. 8b). Additionally, the appearance of Cu2+ typically around 917.7 eV is indicated by a shoulder in that spectral region, suggesting the presence of Cu2+ [63–67]. It is concluded that a combination of Cu2+ and Cu+ is evident in all the catalysts. Analysis of Auger spectrums also confirmed that the ratios of Cu+/Cu2+ reached the highest value by increasing the Fe content in CuFe2 catalyst, and further increase in the Fe content resulted in a lower intensity of the copper peaks on the surface of catalyst, which was also confirmed in XPS and EDS analysis. Analysis of Auger spectra also confirmed that the ratios of Cu+/Cu2+ reached their highest values with increasing Fe content (in the CuFe2 catalyst). Furthermore, a further increase in Fe content led to a decrease in the Cu+/Cu2+ ratios and intensity of the copper peaks, on the catalyst surface, a finding corroborated by XPS (Table 4) and EDS analyses (Fig. 5). The coexistence of both Cu+ and Cu2+ on the catalyst surface even without a specific catalyst reduction step in the presence of reducing agent could be due to the redox interactions between Fe and Cu (Cu2+ + Fe2+ ↔ Fe3+ + Cu+) during the catalyst preparation, which is supporting the argument that the catalyst composition and preparation procedure can facilitate the oxidation state changes. As mentioned earlier, iron has a slightly lower electronegativity compared to copper, which suggests that in the presence of iron, there can be electron donation to copper. This electron transfer can reduce some of the Cu2+ to Cu+, altering the oxidation state of copper even without an external reducing agent like H2. Often, the preparation conditions of catalysts involve steps that can lead to changes in oxidation states. These include calcination, impregnation, and drying steps, which might occur in environments that allow for oxidation-reduction reactions independent of a specific hydrogen reduction step. Transition metal catalysts, such as those containing Cu and Fe, are known for their active redox behavior, essential for their catalytic efficacy. These catalysts may exhibit internal redox mechanisms that naturally balance the oxidation states of the metals involved based on the conditions and the chemical environment. The higher Cu+/Cu2+ ratio is expected to influence catalytic performance by enhancing catalyst reduction and offering more active sites for the reaction. This higher content of Cu+ is also confirmed by the H2-TPR analysis, with the CuFe1 catalyst exhibiting the highest H2 consumption compared to other catalysts. Based on XPS analysis, the incorporation of a small amount of iron (CuFe1) and the subsequent increase in Cu+/Cu2+ resulted in increased glycerol conversion. A further rise in Fe content led to a lower Cu+/Cu2+ ratio and, and consequently, reduced conversion. The catalyst with the highest iron content (CuFe4) and the lowest Cu+/Cu2+ ratio is expected to exhibit the lowest glycerol conversion, as confirmed by the glycerol hydrogenolysis reaction (Fig. 2). However, the comparable catalytic activities of CuFe3 and Cu catalysts, despite the lower Cu+/Cu2+ in CuFe3 than Cu catalyst, suggest that Cu+ content is not the only factor influencing catalytic performance. Other factors, such as surface properties and acidity, may also play pivotal roles in shaping catalytic performance. The ratio of Cu+/Cu2+ influences the catalysts reducibility (see Fig. 7) so that it has to be taken into consideration in activation procedure. In the frame of this study, all catalysts were activated at 350 °C and a hydrogen pressure of 7 MPa therefore the reduction of Cu oxides to Cu+ can be supposed. The strength and density of the acid sites were assessed through ammonia temperature-programmed desorption (NH3-TPD) analysis ( Fig. 9(a)). The initial peak around 100 °C could be attributed to the desorption of residual NH3 weakly bonded to the catalyst surface, indicating the presence of weak acid sites generated by OH– groups. The peaks observed at higher temperatures, approximately 250 °C and 330 °C, are likely attributed to the desorption of NH3 species more strongly bonded to the catalyst surface, indicating the presence of strong acid sites within the catalyst structure [68,69]. The hydrogenolysis of glycerol can yield several potential products ( Scheme 1), highlighting the importance of achieving high selectivity toward the desired product. Using the acid pathway, glycerol undergoes dehydration to form acetol, which is then hydrogenated to produce 1,2-PD. Conversely, employing the basic pathway, glycerol is initially dehydrogenated to glyceraldehyde, which subsequently undergoes dehydration to yield 2-hydroxypropenal. Through a molecular rearrangement, 2-hydroxypropenal is converted into pyruvaldehyde, both of which can be hydrogenated to generate 1,2-PD. Numerous studies have documented the use of supported metal nanoparticles for selectively converting glycerol to propanediols using H2. The acidity of the catalyst is a crucial factor influencing the catalytic performance, particularly product selectivity [68–71]. Fig. 9(b) illustrates the correlation between the turnover frequency (TOF) and the Fe/Cu ratio, revealing that catalysts with low Fe content, particularly CuFe2, exhibit the highest TOF values. Notably, the initial reaction rate is slightly higher for catalysts with minimal Fe content (CuFe1) compared to the copper-only catalyst (Cu1), but then the reaction rate decreases as the amount of Fe increases. As shown in Fig. 9(d), the CuFe2 catalyst displayed the highest selectivity for 1,2-PD, which can be attributed to its elevated concentration of strong acid sites, as illustrated in Fig. 9(c). Strong acid sites promote the dehydration pathway and metal sites promote dehydrogenation pathway (Scheme 1). The primary hydroxyl group attacked by these strong acid sites to form 1,2-PD via acetol. In contrast, the selectivity of 1,2-ethanedoil (1,2-ED) is lower with increasing number of strong acid sites. Interestingly, total acidity may not be a crucial property for this reaction. With an increase in iron content, the strong sites decreased, resulting in a corresponding decrease in 1,2-PD selectivity. On the other hand, weak acid sites facilitate mechanism different pathway by interacting with the secondary hydroxyl group of glycerol (Scheme 1) [68]. Consequently, catalysts with higher weak acid sites may demonstrate lower selectivity toward the desired product (1,2-PD). The results indicate that acidity plays a major role in product selectivity but is not the only factor affecting catalytic performance. As mentioned previously, physicochemical properties such as metal dispersion, porosity, and cluster size can also impact catalytic performance. In a previous study, the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst with an optimized Cu loading exhibited a selectivity to propanediols of approximately 96.8 % with a glycerol conversion of around 49.6 % under mild reaction conditions (220 °C, initial H2 pressure 1.5 MPa, 10 h, Cu/glycerol molar ratio 3/100) [72]. Other researchers have utilized Ag as a promoter. In this case, the CuAg/Al2O3 catalyst with the optimal Cu and Ag content (molar ratio of Cu/Ag 7:3, 2.7 mmol Cu+Ag per gram γ-Al2O3) demonstrated nearly 100 % selectivity to propanediols with a glycerol conversion of about 27 % under mild reaction conditions (200 °C, initial H2 pressure 1.5 MPa, 10 h, molar ratio (Cu+Ag)/glycerol 3/100) [73]. Previous studies have demonstrated that Ag loading below 1 wt% inversely correlates with EG selectivity, and selectivity to EG decreases with increasing Ag loading at Ag loadings below 1 wt%. Specifically, the Cu/Al2O3 catalyst with 1 % Ag exhibited the lowest EG selectivity of 1.6 %, while achieving the highest 1,2-PDO selectivity of 96.2 % and complete glycerol conversion [21]. Furthermore, Pudi et al. [27] compared monometallic Cu and Ni catalysts on alumina with a bimetallic Cu-Ni catalyst (1:1 ratio) at 210°C and 4.5 MPa, revealing that the bimetallic catalyst attained a 1,2-PD selectivity of 92.8 % at a glycerol conversion of 72 %. In another study [35], catalysts with Zn as a promoter were evaluated. At a temperature of 200 °C and a hydrogen pressure of 400 psi (∼2.76 MPa), the glycerol conversion and 1,2-PD selectivity catalyzed by a Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst prepared via oxalate gel co-precipitation were 92.3 % and 94.5 %, respectively. In a recent investigation a Cu/Al2O3 catalyst supported on boron oxide (B2O3) [23] was studied in the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol and crude glycerol (a by-product or waste stream from the biodiesel industry) to produce 1,2-PDO. Under optimized conditions (temperature of 250 °C, H2 pressure of 6 MPa, weight hourly space velocity (WHSV) of 0.1 h-1, and using a 5Cu-B/Al2O3 catalyst), a 10 wt% aqueous glycerol solution was converted to 1,2-PD with a glycerol conversion of 98 ± 2 % and a selectivity of 98 ± 2 %. In comparison to the findings of previous research on glycerol hydrogenolysis, the Fe-supplemented catalysts in this study demonstrated excellent glycerol conversion and selectivity towards 1,2-PD. Notably, the CuFe2 catalyst, with a molar ratio of Fe/Cu=0.15, yielded the most promising results, achieving 96 % glycerol conversion and 95 % selectivity for 1,2-PD under conditions of 230 °C, 7 MPa, and an 80 % w/w aqueous glycerol solution with a W/F ratio of 0.6 h. 4 Conclusions This study presents a novel Cu-based catalyst tailored for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol. The catalyst, prepared by a simple and cheap method, i.e. impregnation of γ-alumina with aqueous solutions of Cu and Fe nitrates at varying Fe/Cu ratios, featured high conversion and selectivity in glycerol hydrogenolysis. Practically full conversion of glycerol and the selectivity above 90 % could be achieved at optimal conditions. All synthesized catalysts exhibited mesoporous characteristics within the range of 5–15 nm. The effect of Fe addition on the main catalyst characteristics was studied. The testing of catalysts was performed at relatively high feed rate where the glycerol conversion was considerably below 100 % so the differences among the reaction rates, degrees of conversion and other reaction characteristics can be more apparent. It was found that the addition of a small amount of Fe (up to Fe/Cu = 0.1) had a positive effect on the glycerol conversion and selectivity as well while further increase of Fe concentration led to gradual deterioration of catalysts performance. Though iron itself has practically zero conversion, as verified by the test, it was found as having several different modifying effects on Cu based catalyst. Firstly, a minor quantity of iron enhanced the crystallinity of the CuO phase on the catalyst surface in its oxidic form. Furthermore, the addition of a small amount of iron led to the creation of slightly larger copper clusters on the catalyst surface, improving their reducibility. Additionally, N2O-RFC analysis confirmed an increase in Cu cluster size, resulting in a weaker metal-support interaction and higher reducibility. Conversely, higher Fe contents led to smaller Cu clusters. Moreover, XPS analysis revealed an increase in Cu+ content with a small addition of Fe, followed by a decrease in the Cu+/Cu2+ ratio at higher Fe content. Elemental mapping indicated the important role of Fe as a metal concentration profile modifier. It was found that lower Fe content, corresponding to Fe/Cu content up to 0.1, led to the increase of Cu concentration near the catalyst particle surface, creating thus almost egg-shell concentration profile, while the Fe content above said limit resulted gradually in more homogeneous Cu concentration profile, which was connected with gradual decrease of conversion. The reason was, that Cu on the catalyst particle surface, or immediately below it was easily accessible for glycerol molecules. The acidity of the catalyst played an important role mainly in the selectivity to 1,2-propanediol. Strong acid sites were found to be associated with increased 1,2-propanediol selectivity. Conversely, higher concentration of weak acid sites caused a decrease of the selectivity towards 1,2-propanediol. These findings highlight the complex relationship between catalyst composition, and catalytic performance, conversion and selectivity, providing valuable insights for the design of optimized catalysts. The catalyst described in this study may have an interesting industrial potential as it represents a very simple to prepare, high performance variant potentially utilizable in 1,2-propanediol production. It is also a very important feature of this catalyst that mechanically resistant particles of γ-alumina are used as the carrier in its preparation so that the catalyst overcomes main weakness of the bulk types of catalysts, i.e. their poor mechanical strength. coredata.dc:description: This study introduces a novel Cu-based catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol to 1,2-propanediol, synthesized by impregnating mesoporous γ-alumina with Cu and Fe. Characterization was performed using various analytical methods, and tests were conducted in a tubular continuous reactor under specific conditions. Iron was found to have multiple modifying effects, influencing the modification of Cu clusters on the catalyst surface and the radial Cu concentration profile inside the particles. A low Fe/Cu ratio resulted in an almost egg-shell Cu profile, whereas higher Fe levels produced a more uniform distribution. Interestingly, minor Fe additions led to larger Cu clusters, while higher amounts resulted in smaller clusters and decreased glycerol conversion. The effect of Fe on Cu clusters size, acid sites concentration, and Cu radial profile, as well as the influence of these parameters on the glycerol conversion and selectivity towards 1,2-PD are discussed in this study.

coredata.dc:title: Iron-modified Cu/γ-alumina catalyst for the selective hydrogenolysis of glycerol
